questions.question: What is the most common anatomical position of the appendix?
Which of the following is not true regarding the various anatomical positions of theappendix?

options.A: Tenderness may be elicited on the immediate right of the umbilicus in post-ileal appendicitis
options.B: The most common location of the base of the appendix is retro-caecal
options.C: An inflamed pelvic appendix may cause an increase in frequency of micturition
options.D: Post-ileal appendicitis may have diarrhoea as a presenting complaint

questions.explanation: The base of the appendix is found at the confluence of the three taeniae coli of the caecum. Itsposition is constant. Conversely, the tip of the appendix can be found in many positions (retrocaecal being the most common)The taeniae coli fuse to form the longitudinal muscle coat of the appendix. During surgery, gentletraction at the taenia coli, leads the surgeon to the base of the appendix.

questions.question: During an appendectomy, the mesoappendix is divided and ligated. Which of the following isfalse about the major vessel ligated in this step?

options.B: It is a branch of upper division of the ileocolic artery
options.D: Thrombosis is most common at the tip

questions.explanation: Positions of appendixRetrocaecal - 74%Paracaecal2%MARROWPreileal - 1%Postileal-0.5%Pelvic-21%Subcaecal1.5%549During appendectomy, the appendicular artery is the major vessel that is ligated when themesoappendix is divided. It is a branch of the lower division of the ileocolic artery.HARMOThe appendicular artery transverses behind the terminal ileum and enters themesoappendix away from the base of the appendix. It lies along the free border of themesoappendix. The terminal part or the tip of the artery lies on the wall of the appendix and maybecome thrombosed in appendicitis, resulting in distal gangrene or necrosis.It supplies only the appendix and is an end-artery.An accessory appendicular artery called the artery of Seshachalam may be present. It anastomosesat the base of the appendix with a branch of the posterior cecal artery.Blood supply of large intestine

questions.question: The CECT findings of a patient who presented with a positive McBurney's sign show a dilatedappendix, appendicular wall thickening, and fat stranding. What is the initiating event thatleads to his condition?
questions.explanation: The clinical scenario is suggestive of appendicitis. The initiating event in the development ofappendicitis is luminal obstruction.Deep tenderness at McBurney's point, known as McBurney's sign, is a sign of acuteappendicitis. McBurney's point is a point at one-third of the distance from the anterior superioriliac spine and umbilicus. It is where the appendix is commonly located.Due to the relatively small diameter of the appendicular lumen, it is easily obstructed. Usually,due to fecoliths. This leads to the buildup of mucus secretions and air due to bacteria. Withprogressive dilation, venous drainage may get hampered, leading to full-thickness ischemia andperforation.Obstructed lumen of appendix → Retained secretions with distension of lumen → Secretions getinfected → Venous occlussion due to increased pressure → Bacterial translocation → Gangrene& perforation Appendicular abscess551

questions.question: What is the earliest symptom in a patient with acute appendicitis?
questions.explanation: Symptoms of acute appendicitis begin as periumbilical pain followed by anorexia and nausea.Acute appendicitis begins with poorly localized colicky abdominal pain, first noticed in theperiumbilical region. This is due to midgut visceral discomfort (T8 to T10 dermatomes) inresponse to appendiceal inflammation and obstruction.Over the next 12-24 hours, it localises to the right lower quadrant due to local peritonealinflammation.

questions.question: A patient presents to the casualty with right lower abdominal pain, nausea, and fever. Onexamination, there is increased pain in the right lower quadrant when palpating the left lowerquadrant. What is this sign is called?
questions.explanation: The given triad of clinical features, namely fever, nausea and right lower abdominal pain isMurphy's triad. It is suggestive of acute appendicitis. Deep palpation of the left iliac fossa cancause pain in the right iliac fossa. This sign is called Rovsing's sign.This pain is due to the backflow of gases from the colon into the inflamed right intestine whenthe left lower abdomen is palpated.

questions.question: 540You are examining a patient suspected to have appendicitis. During the given manoeuvre, younotice that the patient has sharp right-sided abdominal pain. Which of the followingstatements is false?

options.A: This sign elicited is known as Psoas Sign
options.B: It is commonly associated with pelvic appendicitis
options.C: Flexion of the hip against resistance may be done instead
options.D: Pain is due to contact of inflamed appendix with the psoas muscle

questions.explanation: The manoeuvre in the given image shows hyperextension of the hip joint. It can induce abdominalpain when there is irritation of the psoas muscle by the inflamed appendix. This is known as thepsoas sign and is commonly seen in retrocecal appendicitis.Flexion of the hip against resistance also elicits the psoas sign.Pain elicited on hip flexion and internal rotation is called the obturator sign. It is commonly seenin pelvic appendicitis.552OMARROW

questions.question: A young boy was brought to the casualty with a history of fever and abdominal pain. Onexamination, he was febrile and his pulse rate was 104 beats/min. The CT scan image isshown below. Which of the following signs is not seen in this disease?541
questions.explanation: The patient's history and radiological findings are indicative of acute appendicitis. Ballance sign isnot seen in acute appendicitis.Findings on CT that are suggestive of acute appendicitis include:•Appendiceal dilatation (>6 mm in diameter)Appendiceal wall thickening (>3 mm) and enhancementBallance sign is seen due to a ruptured spleen. The ballance sign is positive if there is a fixeddullness to percussion in the left flank and shifting dullness to percussion in the right flank. Thefixed dullness is due to the presence of coagulated blood near the lacerated spleen while theshifting dullness is due to the presence of blood in the peritoneal cavity.Option A: Deep tenderness at McBurney's point, known as McBurney's sign, is a sign of acuteappendicitis. McBurney's point is a point at one-third of the distance from the anterior superioriliac spine and umbilicus.Option B: Rovsing sign is seen in appendicitis. Deep palpation of the left iliac fossa may causepain in the right iliac fossa.Option C: Psoas sign is seen in appendicitis. Occasionally, an in■amed appendix lies on the psoasmuscle, and the patient will lie with the right hip exed, for pain relief.

In the pediatric population, ultrasound ofthe abdomen is the preferred imaging modality to identify the presence of an inflamed appendix.It avoids the risk of radiation exposure.553In adults, the best imaging modality is a CT scan.

questions.question: A patient presents with fever and right lower quadrant pain for the past week. Onexamination, tenderness and guarding in the right iliac fossa are present. An ill-definedabdominal mass is also palpated. CBC reveals leucocytosis. What is the next step inmanagement?
questions.explanation: In appendicular mass, the inflammatory process is already localized and any surgical interventionmay be difficult and dangerous. Hence, if the general condition is satisfactory, the conservativeOchsner-Sherren regimen is used.

questions.question: Identify the incision made on a patient while performing an appendicectomy.543
questions.explanation: Lanz incision is a transverse skin crease incision for appendicitis 2 cm below the umbilicus,centered on the midclavicular—mid inguinal line554Option A: Gridiron incision is an oblique muscle-splitting incision in the right lower quadrant. Itis also called McBurney incision.Option C: Rutherford-Morrison incision is an oblique muscle-cutting incision with its lower endover McBurney's point and extending obliquely upwards and laterally as necessary(Shown on theleft side in the image for the sake of clarity)Option D: Rockey-Davis incision is a transverse right lower quadrant incision.Grid ironincisionLanzincisionIncisions used in appendicectomyMARROWRutherfordMorrison'sincisionLowermidlineabdominalincision

questions.question: A surgeon performs an appendicectomy with a grid iron incision. He later converts theincision to Rutherford Morrison incision. Which of the following are cut?
questions.explanation: The structures cut when the initial incision gridiron incision (McBurney's incision) is converted tothe Rutherford Morrison incision are the external oblique, internal oblique, and transverseabdominis muscles.When the preoperative diagnosis is reasonably certain, the widely used incision for appendectomyis known as the gridiron incision. It is made perpendicular to a line connecting the anteriorsuperior iliac spine to the umbilicus, with its center at McBurney's point. When better access isneeded, the gridiron incision can be converted to a Rutherford Morison incision by extending theincision obliquely upwards and laterally.Rutherford Morison's incision is suitable for a para- or retrocecal appendix that is fixed. It is anoblique muscle-cutting incision starting from McBurney's point and extending upward andlaterally as needed. All layers (skin, subcutaneous tissues, external oblique, internaloblique, transversus abdominis, and the peritoneum) are divided along the incision line.In recent years, the transverse skin crease (Lanz) incision has gained popularity due to improvedexposure and ease of extension when necessary. This incision is placed approximately 2 cm belowthe umbilicus along the midclavicular-midinguinal line, with its length adjusted according to thepatient's size and obesity. If required, the incision can be extended medially by retracting ordividing the rectus abdominis muscle (statement 4).555When there is uncertainty in the diagnosis, especially in the presence of intestinal obstruction, alower midline abdominal incision is preferred over a right lower paramedian incision.Incisions used in appendicectomyGrid ironincisionLanzincisionMARROWRutherfordMorrison'sincisionLowermidlineabdominalincision

questions.question: As a surgical resident performing an appendectomy, what is the maximum stump size thatyou can leave behind in order to prevent stump appendicitis?
questions.explanation: The residual appendiceal stump should be no longer than 5 mm, so as to minimize the possibilityof stump appendicitis in the future.Stump appendicitis is a complication that occurs after an appendectomy. It is caused by theinflammation of the residual appendiceal tissue after the appendix is removed. The clinicalpresentation of stump appendicitis is similar to acute appendicitis.Factors predisposing for stump appendicitis:• Inadequate identification of the appendicular base due to severe local inflammation• Leaving a long stump due to fear of cecal injury or difficult dissection.• Local ulcerations due to fecoliths.

questions.question: What is the most common post-operative complication that may arise in patients whoundergo an appendectomy?
questions.explanation: Wound infection is the most common postoperative complication of appendectomy.559

questions.question: What is the most common neoplasm of the appendix ?545
questions.explanation: The most common neoplasm primarily identified in the appendix are carcinoid tumors.They account for approximately 66% of all tumors of the appendix. They are detected in 0.3 to0.9% of appendectomy specimens.Adenocarcinoma of the appendix is very rare, accounting for 0.5% of all gastrointestinal cancers.The adenocarcinoma malignancies are three subtypes:•Mucinous• Colonic type• AdenocarcinoidMucinous is the most common subtype whereas Adenocarcinoid is the rarest.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is false about carcinoid tumours of appendix?

options.A: Size appears to be the best predictor of malignant behavior and metastatic potential
options.B: Arise from Kulchitsky cells of the crypts of Lieberkühn
options.C: Most common location is the base of the appendix

questions.explanation: The most common location of the carcinoid tumour of the appendix is the tip of the appendix i.e.,the distal third of the appendix.A carcinoid tumour, also known as argentaffinoma, arises in argentaffin tissue (Kulchitsky cells ofthe crypts of Lieberkühn). It often presents with symptoms of subacute or recurrent appendicitis.On gross examination, it is a moderately hard, yellow tumour between the intact mucosa and theperitoneum. Microscopically, tumour cells are small, arranged in small nests within the muscle,and have a characteristic pattern using immunohistochemical stain for chromogranin B.Carcinoid tumours are the most common appendiceal tumours but they rarely metastasize.Treatment includes appendicectomy. Indications for right hemicolectomy along withappendectomy are:•• Involvement of the cecal wall.Tumour is 2 cm or more in size•Lymph nodes are involved.

questions.question: A 35-year-old female patient is admitted to the hospital for complaints of pain and tendernessin the right iliac fossa. She underwent an appendicectomy. A 2.5 cm tumor was encounteredat the base of the appendix which was found to be carcinoid on histopathologicalexamination. What is the next step in management?

options.B: Send the urine for 5- hydroxy indole acetic acid levels

questions.explanation: The carcinoid tumors of the appendix which are more than 2 cm in size are treated with righthemicolectomy.Management of carcinoid tumors:• <1 cm Appendicectomy-560• 1-2 cms - Appendicectomy or right hemicolectomy depending on the individual tumorcharacteristics.•>2 cm - Right hemicolectomyIrrespective of size, it is recommended to perform a right hemicolectomy in:• Carcinoids at the appendiceal base (<2 cm from the base)••• Lymphatic invasion or lymph node involvementSpread to the mesoappendix• Tumor-positive resection margins• Cellular pleomorphism with a high mitotic index.

questions.question: Following an appendectomy, the specimen was sent for HPE. A well-circumscribed, yellowishtumor measuring 0.5 cm in diameter at the tip of the appendix was seen. The stained sectionsrevealed a typical carcinoid tumor of the appendix. The specimen had a tumor-free margin onall sides. The base of the appendix, the mesoappendix, and nodes were not involved. What isthe next step of management?
questions.explanation: The size of the carcinoid tumour is 0.5 cm (<1 cm), the margins of the resected specimen aretumour free, and there is no involvement of appendix base, mesoappendix, or lymph nodes. Thebest management approach here is observation.Carcinoid tumour may be detected in ~0.5% of appendectomy specimens. Appendectomy isadequate in the treatment of cases with a diameter of <1 cm and in those with a diameter of 1-2cm without lymphovascular invasion.If a tumour is found after appendicectomy:• If it is an adenocarcinoma, perform right hemicolectomy.• If it is a carcinoid tumour, treatment differs according to the tumour size:• <1 cm Observation-• 1–2 cm – Right hemicolectomy if a lymphovascular invasion is seenRight hemicolectomy treatment is indicated even in tumours < 2 cm in case of:•>2 cm - Right hemicolectomy•Tumours localized at the base of the appendix• Invasion of lymphatic ducts, serosa and mesoappendix• Presence of regional lymph node metastasis• Positive surgical margins•• Mucin production (mucinous carcinoid tumours)• High mitotic fast cellular pleomorphism

questions.question: A 6-year-old presented with right lower quadrant pain and fever for 1 day. An appendicitiswas suspected and the patient was prepared for surgery. During the surgery, a normalappendix was found but mesenteric lymph nodes were enlarged. What is the most likelydiagnosis?
questions.explanation: Yersinia enterocolitica causes inflammation of the terminal ileum, appendix, and cecum,alongwith mesenteric lymphadenopathy. It is the most common differential diagnosis of acute561appendicitis.Acute mesenteric lymphadenitis manifests as acute right lower quadrant abdominal painassociated with mesenteric lymph node enlargement and a normal appendix. Diagnosis is madeafter exploration of the abdomen of a patient suspected of having acute appendicitis, whichreveals a normal appendix and enlarged mesenteric lymph nodes. It usually occurs in childrenand young adults.

questions.question: A postmenopausal lady diagnosed with mucinous cystadenoma appendix is unwilling forsurgery. A few weeks later, she complains of vague abdominal pain and progressiveabdominal distension. Ultrasound reveals the presence of ascites. CT reveals a thickenedperitoneum, multiple loculated fluid collections, and scalloping of the liver and spleenmargin. Which of the following statements is false regarding her condition?

options.A: The patient is most likely suffering from disseminated peritoneal carcinomatosis
options.B: The histology of the appendiceal tumor is an important predictor of survival
options.C: Cytoreductive surgery with IPHC maybe required for management
options.D: This condition can also occur in patients with ovarian neoplasms

questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario of a patient with mucinous cystadenoma appendix and imagingfindings are suggestive of pseudomyxoma peritonei.Pseudomyxoma peritonei refers to a condition of mucinous ascites arising due to the rupture of amucinous tumor of appendix or ovary. It most commonly occurs in patients between 40-50 yearsof age. They are often asymptomatic or present with non-specific complaints like abdominal painand distension.Physical examination may reveal ascites with non shifting dullness and rarely, a palpableabdominal mass. CT scan may reveal accumulation of mucinous material and scallopedindentation of the visceral surfaces of the liver and spleen. The peritoneal surfaces may bethickened due to the solid components of the tumor. The histology of the primary appendicealtumor is an important predictor of survival.Management consists of extensive resection of the tumor (cytoreduction) and intraperitonealheated chemotherapy (IPHC). Surgical management may include omentectomy, resection of theperitoneum and involved organs, appendectomy or a right hemicolectomy.562
